content:
The Act is titled the "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" and includes provisions for project management oversight by the Deputy Director for Management, who is responsible for adopting governmentwide standards, policies, and guidelines for program and project management in executive agencies. The Act, titled the "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act," mandates the establishment of standards and policies for executive agencies, engagement with the private sector to identify best practices, conducting portfolio reviews of high-risk programs, and developing a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Act requires the establishment of a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Department of Defense is exempt if similar provisions are already in place. The Deputy Director for Management must issue standards, policies, and guidelines within a year of the Act's enactment. Regulations must be issued within 90 days. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Program Management Policy Council, shall issue regulations to implement the requirements of section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Additionally, Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for Program Management Improvement Officers and a Program Management Policy Council. Sec. 1126 establishes Program Management Improvement Officers in agencies to implement program management policies and enhance the role of program managers through training and educational opportunities. Training in relevant competencies for program and project managers in the private sector, emphasizing cost containment for large projects and programs. The curr_chunk discusses mentoring, career paths, recruitment, best practices dissemination, and data analysis tools for program managers. It does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions are already in place. The provisions in this subsection are similar to chapter 87 of title 10. The Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics is considered the Program Management Improvement Officer. A Program Management Policy Council is established in the Office of Management and Budget to improve agency practices related to program and project management. The Program Management Policy Council in the Office of Management and Budget is responsible for reviewing high-risk programs, discussing workforce development needs, advising on program management transparency standards, and reviewing information published on the OMB website. The Program Management Policy Council in the Office of Management and Budget oversees high-risk programs, workforce development, program management transparency, and OMB website information. The Council is composed of five members from the Office of Management and Budget. The Program Management Policy Council in the Office of Management and Budget is composed of five key members:
- Deputy Director for Management
- Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government
- Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy
- Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management
- Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management The Program Management Improvement Officer from each agency and other designated federal employees or Armed Forces members are part of the Council. The Chairperson is the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, with a Vice Chairperson elected by members for a term of up to 1 year. The Chairperson leads meetings, sets the agenda, directs the Council's work, and establishes subgroups as needed. The Council, led by the Chairperson, meets at least twice a year with support from agency heads. A report must be submitted to Congress within a year, outlining the strategy developed by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must issue regulations within 180 days of the issuance of standards, policies, and guidelines under section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. These regulations will identify key skills and competencies needed for program and project managers in agencies, establish or update job series for program and project management within agencies. The Government Accountability Office will issue a report on the effectiveness of policies for improving Federal program and project management, including standards, policies, guidelines, and the strategic plan established under section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. The Program Management Improvement Officers and the Program Management Policy Council were designated under section 1126 of title 31, United States Code.
